title: Depositary receipt
text:
A depositary receipt (DR) is a negotiable financial instrument issued by a bank to represent a foreign company's <a href="Public%20company">publicly traded</a> <a href="Security%20%28finance%29">securities</a>. The depositary receipt trades on a local <a href="stock%20exchange">stock exchange</a>. Depositary receipts facilitates buying shares in foreign companies, because the shares do not have to leave the home country.
Depositary receipts that are listed and traded in the United States are <a href="American%20depositary%20receipt">American depositary receipt</a>s (ADRs). European banks issue <a href="European%20depositary%20receipt">European depositary receipt</a>s (EDRs), and other banks issue <a href="global%20depository%20receipts">global depository receipts</a> (GDRs).
How it works.
A depositary receipt typically requires a company to meet a stock exchange’s specific rules before listing its stock for sale. For example, a company must transfer shares to a <a href="brokerage">brokerage</a> house in its home country. Upon receipt, the brokerage uses a <a href="custodian%20bank">custodian</a> connected to the international stock exchange for selling the depositary receipts. This connection ensures that the shares of stock actually exist and no manipulation occurs between the foreign company and the international brokerage house.
